key_points: Twitter and Facebook suspended President Donald Trump's accounts following the storming of the U.S. Capitol by his supporters.
This marks the most aggressive action the social media companies have taken against Trump.
Twitter locked Trump's account for 12 hours and required the removal of three of his tweets.
Facebook and Instagram (owned by Facebook) announced a 24-hour suspension of Trump's account due to policy violations.
Experts argue the social media platforms' actions were too late, citing Trump's repeated use of social media to spread misinformation and incite violence.
Communications professor Jennifer Grygiel highlighted the platforms' responsibility in Trump's propagation of propaganda and disinformation.
Facebook's vice-president of integrity, Guy Rosen, stated the action was emergency measures due to ongoing violence risks.
The incident interrupts the confirmation of electoral college results and President-elect Joe Biden's victory.
Critics, including the Anti-Defamation League, called for Trump's permanent ban from social media platforms.
Trump acknowledges defeat and assures an 'orderly transition on January 20th' in a statement posted by his aides.
spokespersons: Jonathan Greenblatt (chief executive officer, Anti-Defamation League)
